author: Victors!
review: Gra bardzo ciekawa, myślę że solidne 8.5/10 jest dobrą oceną ze względu na niedogodności, które opiszę niżej.PLUSY:✔️ ✔️Oprawa audio-wizualna na wysokim poziomie. Tereny jak i Hogwart bardzo dobrze odtworzony. Raytracing robi robotę (co prawda często się buguje, ale zostanie to naprawione w patchu)✔️Gameplay ciekawy, nie nużący po 70H, jednak w niektórych momentach wydaję się za prosty. Zagadki co prawda powtarzające się to jednak wymagające od początkującego gracza.✔️ Gra z godziny na godzine się rozkręca co uważam za plus, nie jest to typowe monotonne bieganie po mapie jak w niektórych innych tytułach z otwartym światem.✔️ Sama główna kampania na jakieś 30-35h, jednak rekomendowane jest wykonywanie pobocznych zadań relacji przed każdym głównym, aby przedłużyć i rozwinąć trochę główną fabułę. Zakończenie nie spoilerując jest raczej standardowe/klasyczne jak na grę tego typu (nie było jakoś zaskakujące).✔️ System levelowania jak i ekwipunek standardowy dla tego typu gier. ✔️ Ciekawy system rzucania zaklęć i odblokowywania ich, jednak ze względu na to, że do głównej kampanii nie ma za dużych wymagań co do odblokowań (gre da się praktycznie przejść mają tylko podstawowe zaklęcia) to psuje to trochę możliwości jakie twórcy maja przy tworzeniu róznych poziomów rozgrywki (stopień skomplikowania zagadek jest niższy niż w pobocznych, często wymaga użycia tego samego schematu zaklęć).✔️ Możliwość skradania się w grze, przejścia poziomów "po cichu" (nie jest to jednak zawsze możliwe, czasami gra "odsłania" gracza automatycznie przed przeciwnikiem/przeciwnicy nadal nas widzą nawet kiedy jesteśmy niewidzialni lub wymaga tego gra)MINUSY:❌ Moim zdaniem animacje postaci i mimika twarzy jest momentami za drętwa (w tych bardziej "dramatycznych" momentach).❌ Powtarzające się teksty i zdania wypowiadane przez główną postać lub też osoby trzecie (np. dwie te same kwestie przy każdorazowym wchodzeniu do Hogsmede, Pokoju Życzeń etc.). Uciążliwe po 70H.❌ Optymalizacja to jest sam w sobie oddzielny problem (najnowszy patch ma to natomiast mocno poprawić). 3090 w 4K (RT/Ultra) osiągała średnio 60fps z DLSS w Hogwart, 30fps w niektórych lasach, 40-45 w Hogsmede, natomiast z spadkami/stutterami co jakiś czas przy ładowaniu terenu itd. (32GB rekomendowane do gry).❌ Kilka niedociągnięć, błędów graficznych z raytracingiem (przebijające światlo przez ściany), cutscenki czasami nie doładowywały na czas tekstur w tle/cieni na postaciach co trochę psuło immersję w niektórych momentach. Błędy pokroju blokowania się postaci na jakiś ścianach/schodach powtarzały się dosyć notorycznie. Wiekszość z tych rzeczy zostanie na pewno naprawione w patchu.❌ Ten sam przycisk usuwania/ustawień w menu, przez co przypadkowo można było skasować save gry.❌ Z kilka razy podczas 75H gameplay spotkałem się z błędami, które wymagały wczytania zapisu od nowa (np. zbugowane zejście z miotły, nie dało sie z niej nigdzie zejść)❌ System ekwipunku mógłby posiadać kilka dodatkowych opcji np. blokowanie wyglądu postaci, aby nie trzeba było przy każdej zmianie ubrania zmieniać wygląd na ten co był wcześniej.❌ Niektóre elementy menu wyzwań niezbyt intuicyjne na poczatku (np. pamiętanie o odbiorze nagród za dane wyzwanie, za każdym razem kiedy je się wykona, co prawda gra przypomina o tym co jakiś czas na dole ekranu)❌ Model latania początkowo wymagający (pad), jedna gałka służy za skręcia lewo/prawo, druga za góra/dół oraz kamere co przeszkadza początkowo w locie (z tego co wiem, nie da się tego zmienić w ustawieniach). EN VERSION:The game is very interesting, I think a solid 8.5/10 is a good rating due to the inconveniences that I will describe below.PROS:✔️ ✔️ Audio-visual setting at a high level. The grounds and Hogwarts are very well recreated. Raytracing does the job (although it often bugs, but it will be fixed in the patch)✔️Gameplay interesting, not boring after 70H, but at some moments it seems too simple. Although the puzzles are repetitive, they are demanding from a novice player.✔️ The game is getting started every hour, which I consider a plus, it's not a typical monotonous running around the map like in some other open-world titles.✔️ The main campaign alone for about 30-35h, however, it is recommended to complete side relationship quests before each main one to extend and develop the main storyline a bit. The ending without spoilers is rather standard/classic for a game of this type (it wasn't surprising at all).✔️ Leveling system as well as standard equipment for this type of games.✔️ An interesting system of casting spells and unlocking them, but due to the fact that the main campaign does not have too high requirements for unlocking (the game is practically possible to pass only basic spells) it spoils the possibilities that the creators have when creating different levels gameplay (the level of complexity of the puzzles is lower than in the side ones, they often require the use of the same spell scheme).✔️ The ability to sneak in the game, pass levels "silently" (however, this is not always possible, sometimes the game "reveals" the player automatically from the opponent / opponents still see us even when we are invisible or the game requires it)CONS:❌ In my opinion, character animations and facial expressions are sometimes too numb (in these more "dramatic" moments).❌ Repetitive texts and sentences spoken by the main character or third parties (e.g. two of the same lines every time you enter Hogsmede, Room of Requirement, etc.). Nuisance after 70H.❌ Optimization is a separate problem in itself (the latest patch is supposed to improve it a lot). 3090 in 4K (RT/Ultra) averaged 60fps with DLSS in Hogwarts, 30fps in some forests, 40-45 in Hogsmede, while with occasional drops/stutters when loading terrain etc. (32GB recommended for the game).❌ A few shortcomings, graphical errors with raytracing (light shining through the walls), cutscenes sometimes did not recharge the background textures / shadows on the characters on time, which spoiled the immersion at some moments. Bugs like characters getting stuck on some walls/stairs were repeated quite notoriously. Most of these things will be fixed in the patch for sure.❌ The same delete/settings button in the menu, which could accidentally delete the game save.❌ Several times during 75H gameplay I encountered errors that required reloading the save (e.g. bugged descent from the broom, it was impossible to get off it anywhere)❌ The equipment system could have a few additional options, e.g. blocking the character's appearance, so that you don't have to change the appearance to what it was before every time you change clothes.❌ Some elements of the challenge menu are not very intuitive at the beginning (e.g. remembering to collect rewards for a given challenge every time you complete it, although the game reminds you about it from time to time at the bottom of the screen)❌ The flying model is initially demanding (pad), one knob is used for turning left / right, the other for up / down and the camera, which initially interferes with the flight (as far as I know, it cannot be changed in the settings).

author: general.kronos
review: I strongly believe that this game would not be as popular if it wasn't about the world of Harry Potter. There is an obvious love for visual details in the game, but there is not much substance behind it. The common rooms look beautiful, but there is absolutely nothing to do in them, you cannot talk to the npc's there, you cannot sit in a chair or sleep in your bed... These are but  a few minor details, but indicative of a bigger problem with the game; there is no immersion, your character does not seem to be part of the world. You cannot interact with most NPCs. they do not react to your spells, the dialogue options mostly do not matter for the progression of the story, there is no real day/night cycle (There is day and night, but shops are also open in the night, vendors do not seem to sleep or go out of their shop).After a few hours the combat gets repetitive, there is not a lot of enemy variety, the number of brewable potions and of plants is low. There is no real excitement of which spells you will be able to learn because the UI shows you all the spells and their names from the beginning, they are simply not selectable. The "unforgivable" curses are totally forgivable, there is 0 consequences to using them, during missions you can use them right next to your professor and he won't care in the slightest...Most hidden areas just contain a single chest with randomly generated loot. Your gear slots are very limited so you will have to fast travel a lot to vendors simply to get rid of the loot. Your gear is upgradeable, but I never bothered to upgrade it and under normal difficulty there really seems to be no reason to upgrade it.Finally there is a ton of collectibles (field pages, chests etc...) But these mostly to have been put in there to artificially add playing hours which provide little entertainement.I had a few hours of fun in the beginning, exploring the castle etc, but after that the veil fell and I noticed how basic the gameplay is and how unoriginal the main story line is. I would definitely wait for a price drop before buying it.

author: Frost
review: after finishing the game i can say that at first it seems really great but quickly notice a growing list of issues with it. (pretty on the surface but cast revelio and you'll notice how very shallow it is)the world is big yes but feels really dead outside of Hogwarts, its just filled with very stupid repeatable "puzzles" that seem to never end. you did one of them successfully? well that's great now go fly elsewhere and repeat it 1000 times. some of different puzzles will be introduced to you during quests where you do one and then they tell you to do more in your spare time. if you do decide on collecting stuff then for exploration there is also a lot of backtracking, example you run around collecting stuff and end up in 1 room where there are 3 things to collect but 2 of them are locked behind closed doors (and you get the extremely-annoying-to-use spell for it later) or require some spell that you don't have right now. please come back again later lol.The game has an utterly pointless MMO-style (green-blue-purple-orange) loot system. you can finish it with the starter level 1 gear and its just mostly filling your inventory and blocks you from opening chests later because your inventory is full so either destroy it/sell to vendor or just ignore all chests, still you might want to collect some for the looks which you can apply to active gear.rather mediocre story (with a unisex main character without any backstory whatsoever) and even worse boring side quests. starting at 5th year - why? who taught MC about magic before? not important i guess. also the ridiculous scale of things, you're a 5th grader but will take on mythical monsters and deadly mages from organized criminal gangs in combat along the way as a pastime between classes - rather ridiculous.also Hogwarts in 1800s is more diverse than any place in real world lol... in addition to British/European professors there are also ones from Japan, Uganda, India, Persia? they even insert a Korean teacher during an idiotic fetch stuff quest for learning lock-picking... why not include native Americans?! i guess they are not on your representation checklist lmao) no morality system, you can just run around and cast "forbidden" spells while on a quest with your classmates and they will only give some empty comment like, oh looks you're not afraid of dark magic bla bla bla. why is it even so controversial to use "dark magic" anyway, you're telling me its bad to kill someone with it but is ok to blow them up to pieces with a fireball instead??? also the choices you make (and that's limited to being either nice or mean to someone - example, they ask you to recover something for them and you'll return and say im going to keep it etc) along the way really don't matter at all and everything will play out the same way regardless of everything you did.on the positive the combat system is quite fun and using different spell combos feels rewarding. Hogwarts does have this atmosphere like in books/movies. its the only >decent< game in potter universe. also the first for this developer i believe? hopefully the next one will be better. being a big brand with big backers behind it it should've been much more than this.as a slap on the face at the end i found there is one more "main quest" after the ending to do but my level was too low for that - well i'm not going to grind those stupid puzzles for that. bye.overall i don't recommend it for full price but is ok to get it for a discount later on.

author: Preator
review: Hogwarts Legacy is a third-person action-adventure game with some minor RPG and exploration folded into the mix. Set in the Wizarding World universe, this game finally lets you explore the castle of Hogwarts and the surrounding area with near-limitless freedom. But did this game capture the magic of the Harry Potter books and movies? Let's find out below.Hogwarts Legacy takes place in the 1800s, a long while before the events of Harry Potter. You play as a self-named and created character arriving at Hogwarts for his first year starting in the 5th year of school. Almost immediately upon setting off for your year of school, the flying carriage you are riding is involved in an incident where the villain, Ranrok, is after something in your possession.This unravels into a scramble for answers and unlocks your powers as quickly as possible to help your new friends and Hogwarts survive this growing threat. With the help of your mentor Professor Fig and some of the other professors at the school providing you with special assignments to hone your considerable talents, your powers grow significantly and impressively quickly, as well as your understanding of your place in this story.For the most part, the story is actually well-written and provides a lot of nostalgia for fans of the WW series. But this is ultimately undone by the lack of fluidity, flow and at times, rushed plot points that litter the entire game. You finally feel invested in a storyline, blazed through in a single mission and forgotten. Pretty sad as this story could have been expanded and would have been sensational.Hogwarts Legacy has quite a considerable repertoire of spells you can unlock and use throughout the story and exploration. Some spells are best utilised for puzzles and activities, and others are more combat proficient.Spells also fall into colour categories which help differentiate them for their use, as well as their purpose in combat. Purple shields can only be damaged by purple or "force" spells, yellow shields can only be broken by yellow or "control" spells and so on. Falling into one of the categories, Control, Force, Damage, Essential, Utility and Unforgivable. Unforgivable curses are broken as they can break any shield colour and dominate combat quite easily.Exploration plays a large part in the game, even though you won't need to or get much time to explore until you're finished with the rather lengthy tutorial. The best items can only be located by exploring dark caves and dungeons.I have to admit, however, while exploring was fun and fascinating in the first part of the game, it became more tedious in the latter, and I tended to avoid it entirely.Flying!!! I absolutely adore flying around on the broom or on the back of a creature and experiencing the world from way above it. There is just something absolutely captivating about it!But Hogwarts Legacy also doesn't have Quidditch in it, removing the main reason people would want to fly around. With fast travel available that is lore-friendly, there is already a quick means of travelling the world. They just removed a reason to get good at flying.This is the part where I'm going to cover a lot of little annoyances and missing content that bothered me during the game.Morality.There is none. You have the ability to cast both light and dark magic, but nobody really cares about it. There is no downside to killing people outright with Avada Kedavra, just as there's no reason to avoid it.Day/Night Cycle.Time does continue to tick as you play the game, and day and night do come to pass, but these events don't mean anything either. When you wake up in your dorm there is nobody still in their beds, and you are all alone. The school empties out for a few hours, but nobody is roaming the halls looking for students.Houses and house points.Joining one of the four houses, Gryffindor, Slytherin, Hufflepuff, and Ravenclaw should mean something, but really they are just a mild aesthetic kick and have no real purpose. You don't gain points for your house by being a good student or doing complex challenges, and you will win the house cup regardless of your effort.This title is beautiful. Landscapes will capture your breath, and the amount of detail put into the world's design and development is astounding. Probably one of the most impressive graphical experiences available today. Particle effects from spells and the overall ambience are above the standard.The audio falls into a very similar basket. The ambience of waves crashing against rocks, trees rustling in the wind and birds chirping as they fly by is brilliantly captivating. While the soundtrack captures nostalgia and wonderment that the movies did so perfectlyRunning the game on high and set to 2560 x 1440 resolution, I never saw the game drop below 60 FPS. Ultra RTX did cause the game to chug quite viciously, however, but was fine as soon as I turned it down to high. I also didn't experience any significant bugs or issues whilst playing the game, which is impressive.RAM: 32GB (Under Load Usage: 58%)CPU: i9 10900KA 3.70GHz (Under Load Usage: 13.4%)GPU: MSI Ventus RTX 3080 (Under Load Usage: 70%)While I had a lot of nitpicks to say about this game, the overall experience wasn't bad at all. Was it worth the current price? No, not really, Was it fun? Yeah, it was, and I thoroughly enjoyed it for what it was. If you're a fan of the franchise, give this game a shot, but I would suggest waiting for a decent sale as I don't think there's enough here to warrant the price.

author: Kirito
review: please fix stuttering and FPS drop

author: SirSaltmineBling
review: This game is one of the best games Ive played in a while.

author: Crowzer
review: Just finished Hogwarts Legacy and it's an excellent game !Even if there are flaws, Hogwarts Legacy conquered me. I'm not a big fan of Harry Potter (I watched all the movies and read a couple of books) but I like the universe and I had a ton of fun in Hogwarts Legacy.The main story is quite engaging and the companion ones are also intriguing (I love the Sebastian story).Hogwarts Legacy combats mechanics are simple but really fun. Only 26 spells but it was enough and there is a plethora of spells combos.Visual ? I put everything to max (even ray-tracing) and Hogwarts Legacy is fabulous, but indeed, it requires a monster PC.Two interesting features in Hogwarts Legacy are :- Pokemon-like, there are a lot of creatures to catch-up and after, feed/clean them.- Housing. There is big room (which increase with story) where you can decorate as you wish. Furniture is available in the open-world chests.- Character creation is awesome ! Let's talk about the open-world. Well, it's quite generic like Ubisoft games but not that bad. You have a lot of places to explore, destroy poacher camps, visiting other villages, doing quests, etc... Lot of activities to do between main quests.I did almost all the side quests but the 'collectibles' thing inherent in the majority of open-worlds quickly bored me. For example, I only did a few trials of Merlin.Like Wo Long Fallen Dynasty and like the other recent releases on PC, Hogwarts Legacy is badly optimized. There are few guides around to improve framerate and stability but there are no miracles. The Reddit thread named "PC Performance Tips - This got rid of low FPS dips for me and friends" can work for you. It does for me, so you give a try.On Steam Deck : I locked to 45 FPS the game is quite playable but still suffer from framerate drops.Hope Avalanche devs will work on patches for PC version of Hogwarts Legacy.Yes, Hogwarts Legacy is a good RPG than will make busy for hours. Also, if you play on PC, there are a lot of mods for the game. It doesn't seem to be planned at the moment, but I hope there will be DLC in the future.

author: lumen
review: I'd rate this neutral if I could, but having to pick between good and bad I gotta pick the latter I'm afraid:Pro:- the World: Hogwarts is awesome, Hogsmeade is nice. The rest is... serviceable- combat is better than expected- music- visuals- voiceacting- atmosphere (in Hogsmeade/Hogwarts anyway)Cons:- all the copy pasted open world garbage: It's all so basic and identical that I don't think you could even simplify it further. 'Cairn dungeons' is the phrase they use to describe a tunnel of 200m length with a chest at the end. They copy pasted the very same cairn 'dungeon' about 150 times. Spoiler: The tunnel has right, left turn. Don't get lost.- combat falls entirely flat towards the 2nd half. Same enemies, no customization and the stat system shows it's flaws: troll 3 levels above you will 1-2 shot you which is fine, but a troll 5 levels below you can't even touch you.- there's about 10 enemies in this game total. And that's being generous. Goblins/Dark Mages/Trolls/Spiders. These 4 cover 99% of enemies you'll fight.- performance is still fairly poor. It runs okay'ish on higher end hardware but nothing more. And on this point: The promised 'Day 1' patch came 1 week after pre-launch and did little to nothing.- Difficulty: I played on hard and was a breeze. I understand this isn't a Souls game. But there's difficulties for the casuals, where is the difficulty for people who like a challenge?- Controls are kinda clunky, both on controller AND M/KB. Consumable wheel especially.- bunch of minor bugs, but mostly non- consequential. The only notable one for me: unfinishable sidequest (Biscuit)- you spend way too little time in Hogwarts. And the game encourages quicktravel and following the map blindly way too much.- accessibility settings aren't well thought out. I wanted to play without minimap and assistances to stop myself from mindlessly going from one world objective to the other, but there's not even a compass without the minimap...- Hogsmeade? More like Alohomeade. Seriously, there's nothing here other than shops and about 50 Alohomora 'Puzzles'- doesn't matter at all what house you play- this would've been better as a regular RPG focusing on Hogwarts and its immediate surroundings. With a regular character experiencing Hogwarts first time instead of all these grandiose plots. But its Warner Bros, so of course you're some random 5th year who just so happens to be the best wizard of all time. Excelling at everything the moment you touch it.  Oh and your magic is special too of course, no one else has it.- ... and of course you're the hero too, no choices on that matter, no dark path.

author: Zoneling
review: Hogwarts Legacy is the best Harry Potter game to date, but as a game on its own merit, at its current price range, it leaves something to be desired. This game is a  for Harry Potter fans, or fans of the Witcher 3's combat and exploration. This game is very similar to the Witcher 3 in a LOT of ways, from the style of the combat, to the four equippable spells, to the repeating side-mission-esque puzzles and minor boss fights.For everyone else, however, it's a thumbs down. For 60 euros, you're getting maybe 20-25 hours of actual content. The rest is copy+paste side-missions and exploration. Now, the team here has made a AMAZING environment, but its big heavy-hit is nostalgia. Without the nostalgia, the environment is impressive, but not nearly as much as it is for a fan of the series.The story is awful. I'm sorry, but I have to be honest here. It's so bland and childish it's kind of embarassing. And it leaks into the characters and conversations too. The protagonist literally massacres hundreds of dark wizards and goblins, as a 15 year old, and nobody, including themselves, bats an eye at this. The actual main plot is not explored nearly to the extent that I wish it was, instead giving you a moustache-twirling villain, with hopelessly under-explored motives.If you're here looking for the magical story-telling of the books, RUN! It's not here!This is really what ruins the game for me. As I will cover later, the game actually has good characters that I'd love to see more of, but you rarely see more than one of them at a time. You interact with them in the same way that a WoW character interacts with quest NPC's, and that's a real shame.What that means is that the main plot is mainly just you, the bland self-insert, doing literally everything. Sometimes another character is along, but it's just for the ride. You're the chosen one.The combat is good, very good, but it's not THAT good.In fact, the story ruins more than that, because it means that your main interaction with the beautiful environment is just... collectibles. The story utilises the awesome environment so little, in fact, often you are spirited away to completely separate mini-dungeons, where you then fight off boss-goons to advance.Just... why?Oh yeah, and of course, the actual story is also super short, meaning you get very little content for your money. And replayability? Forget it. There are no decisions here. All playthroughs will be the same pretty much, especially if you try to complete your side-quests.The other characters fit well into the Harry Potter universe, without being carbon copies of book characters. In general, I found most of the characters pretty memorable. My favourite was Natty. I just thought she was nice.None of the characters feel out place, and there is a pretty good selection of main characters to interact with. Sadly, only one of these characters really interacts that much with the main story, Professor Fig. He's the only one who is really there from start to finish, and even then only really as a mentor character. You really miss the shenanigans and shared adventures that the books portrayed. Sadly, this just adds insult to the injury that is how they are used in the main story. I NEVER, not even ONCE, felt like I needed any of these characters. Except for teaching me a few spells, I, the main character, do EVERYTHING MYSELF. You don't get the feeling of complimenting talents like you do in the original series at all, it's just you against the goblin horde, assisted by Professor Fig who does boring study-stuff for you.What a waste!The real attraction is the combat. As I mentioned, it's very similar in feel to the Witcher 3. Now, if you've played the Witcher 3, you know that all runes except the protective one are basically useless compared to just hitting stuff with your sword.So imagine the Witcher 3, but with awesome spells, and you have the combat in Hogwars Legacy. If you're good at cycling spell sets, you can do combos with an array of up to 16(!) different spells. The skill ceiling is insanely high on these, and it's a lot of fun to watch the fireworks so to speak, as you sling burning goblins into each other, back to you, set them on fire, and back again. It's A LOT of fun!Oh my goodnees, the environment! This is hands-down the most fun I've had exploring since... ever, probably. You get to bloody fly, and they barely restrict it! And it's awesome! There's so much to see, so much to collect. For completionists like me, it's both a dream and nightmare at the same time.Most places have little lore tid-bits for you to collect and read, and the environment is lovingly hand-crafted, with a real attention to detail. Especially Harry Potter fans will really appreciate it, but honesly I think it's impressive no matter who you are.The only thing that really ruins it a bit, is the population of this world. Similar to early Cyberpunk, the sidewalk characters do.... literally nothing. They just walk around aimlessly, or stand idle in their set positions. Sometimes they say some neat things, but it's generally pretty disappointing when we're so used to better in games these days.But otherwise, the environments of this game are beautiful. Graphically it's a bit last-gen, but the art direction is superb, and to top it off, it actually runs pretty well. At least, it does for me.

author: Homer Morisson
review: As great as the main story and most "relationship line" major side stories are, the world is utterly empty for the most part, there is ZERO "I'm a student at Hogwarts" gameplay outside of 1 or 2 short cutscenes per class, that's it.Your choice of house doesn't matter one bit, your dialogue and behaviour choices are always the exact same no matter if you're Slytherin or Hufflepuff.Using the Dark Arts? No one cares... you can literally cast Avada Kedavra right IN FRONT of your professors, and they do not even react, let alone cause you any consequences whatsoever.Hogwarts itself, while visually impressive to be sure, has zero point zero percent "Sentient Castle" feel... nothing... there aren't even the iconic moving staircases... they only fade in and out visually, but they are nonetheless 100% static, always connecting the same point A to the same point B.Room of Requirement also is a major letdown, as it has zero roleplaying value, it is simply a room full of resource nodes, and the Vivaria are just the same... sure, for a few minutes it might be nice to watch a Hippogriff young offspring frolick about, but that's all you're getting... the animals themselves are also just glorified resource nodes, all you can do is brush, feed, harvest, repeat ad nauseam.The stuff you can summon both in RoR and Vivaria is also just scene dressing... if you were thinking of actually entering that Cottage you spawned in your Vivarium, think again.... if you thought you could sit down on those comfy chairs you just summoned, think again.Same with everything outside of the RoR as well... think you could go to the Great Hall, sit down at your House Table and eat, interact with friends/NPCs of your house, etc? Think again.The few things Hogwarts Legacy does well, it does really well... but everything else, and especially the ending of the main story, where your choices make zero difference, with there not even being any Epilogue to speak of... it all feels very rushed, and the game pretty much in all aspects aside from Main and "Relationship Line" story fails utterly to live up to the potential that is there in abundance.On top of all that, there's the abysmal technical state affecting a huge number of players even on 4090-level gaming rigs, and the fact that the game is massively shorter than what the devs promised... if I hadn't gotten it for free, I would've honestly refunded it, or otherwise felt majorly taken for a ride.Given that the game puts our "Legacy" so front and center, there's very little communication thereof while you play the game... for the most part, there are literally ZERO consequences to your actions, it simply doesn't matter what you do or don't do, if you use the Unforgivable Curses or not, not even what you decide during the crucial final minutes of the story... and as I said above, there isn't even any proper Epilogue, nothing to actually show you how your choices changed the world around you, i.e. what your "Legacy" actually would be.Nothing at all. And that leaves a decidedly bitter aftertaste... so much wasted potential... this game could have been a true masterpiece... as it stands, I cannot in good conscience recommend it for full price.

author: b3
review: Great world-building with a strong sense of immersion. The intro was especially impactful and got me really excited to play the game. Progression is rather slow and narrative heavy, while the combat can be fun and really satisfying.Hogwarts Legacy was fantastic for the first 15+ hours, but somehow it became lacking along the way. Maybe it's because I've played so many "next-gen" AAA titles as of late that Hogwarts itself doesn't feel much different.Maybe I'm growing old.

author: Yoshi
review: Hogwarts Legacy is a dream come true for any Potterhead! While the graphics may not be the most spellbinding, they are still decent and do a good job of bringing the world of Hogwarts to life. The gameplay, however, is as smooth as butterbeer, and the story is a delightful romp through the beloved world of Harry Potter. I was absolutely spellbound by the ability to create my own wizard and attend Hogwarts, experiencing all the magic and wonder I've only ever read about. From casting spells to flying broomsticks, this game has it all. I mean, who wouldn't want to live their own Hogwarts story? Oh and did I mention you can pet the cats?

author: kdodds
review: Excellent game.  Not exactly the skills/stats type of RPG for min/maxers, but for actual roleplaying, it's up there.  The only problem is that it's strongly story driven.  There's not much reward for go it your own way free form exploration.  Still, as an action adveture, it's a very solid and very enjoyable game with tons of stuff to do and plenty of meat to sink your teeth into.  I would not, however, expect to be able to get multiple play throughs out of Hogwart's.  There's just not enough diversiity in character development or story to warrant a second go.  Luckily, there is enough here to get at least a couple hundred hours of gaming.

author: Siavash
review: Hogwarts Legacy has succeeded in presenting players a huge, mysteriously beautiful 'Hogwarts'. While the game expands the franchise's thrilling, magical experience throughout the Highlands, it did not forget the delicate touches for the original fans. It is safe to say that this is the game where the Wizarding World you've dreamed unfolds right before your eyes. it rightfully deserves a 8.5 from 10 . though it worth mentioning it flaws like , extreme frame drops that sometimes its undescribable or most of its side quests are just a simple fetch quest but its undoubtedly one of the best AAA 2023 games that it worth for it price tag and experience .

author: ¤ βℓооđч ¤ Nico-Kun!
review: Allow me to begin this review by saying that, as a Harry Potter fan since I was a kid (practically grew up with the books), Hogwarts Legacy is the Harry Potter game I've always dreamt of, allowing me to finally visit Hogwarts as a student myself, having my own adventures instead of following the plot from the books.The story is set around 100 years before the books. You play as a Hogwarts student who just recently got accepted into the school, and as a fifth year no less! While this may seem weird, as one would expect to start from first year, it's both explained in the story, and honestly allows the player to jump straight into the action, instead of going through the basics. Anyway, at the start of the game, you're just about to depart to Hogwarts alongside Professor Fig, who's been getting you up to speed with some basic spellcasting. Things don't go precisely well on the journey there, and you end up getting involved in the latest goblin rebellion. Honestly, I can say I enjoyed the story, though the best part of the narrative comes through the companion sidequests. While there's four main companions with a certain involvement in the main story (one for each house), only three of them get their own personal side story.When it comes to gameplay, it's an open world action adventure game with some light RPG elements. While there's dialogue choices throughout the game, they don't really affect your relationship with other characters, nor do they lock you out of content (well, you can choose not to learn the Unforgivable Curses). Combat is done through spellcasting, while at first you only have a basic cast, as you progress through the story you unlock new spells, including, as I mentioned above, the Unforgivable Curses. Now, the game basically allows using them willy-nilly, and there's no consequences for going on a murdering spree; of course, it can be excused as you're fighting Dark Wizards and evil goblins. Beyond that, you can also get a broom to get around the map (no Quidditch, though), or even a hippogrif mount. There's also different skill trees in the form of "talents", which give you different upgrades, and while you can craft equipment, you can upgrade certain pieces of equipment. Also, a great plus is that you can change the appearance of your gear to that of any other gear you've found, so you don't end up looking like a madman wearing mismatching clothes.There's lots of stuff to do in this game beyond the main story and the side quests; perhaps too much, at times, as it can feel a bit tedious going for 100% completion. There's different mini puzzles in the form of Merlin trials, broom races, and at one point in the story, you unlock the Room of Requirement, which works as a sort of "base" where you can brew potions or grow plants to use in combat. Plus, you also get to rescue animals and put them in your own personal shelter, treat them well, and they'll give you resources (of course, it can feel a bit morally questionable how you "rescue" animals to get their resources, but the game makes it look like you're at least treating them fairly, and you can even release them to the wild).Graphically, it looks gorgeous. Hogwarts itself is very detailed, as are the surrounding areas. And the map is huge, too; not only do you get to explore Hogwarts, the Forbidden Forest and Hogsmeade, but there's also plenty of little hamlets spread throughout the map, all with their own little collectibles, merchants, and side quests. The sound design is also very good; the dialogue is well written and the performances are all very good, and the soundtrack is excellent; some tracks resemble the movies, but the game has its own style as well.Now, to talk about Hogwarts itself, it's fantastic. The design of the castle resembles that of the movies, but there's still many details you'd find only in the books, including characters; Peeves, the poltergeist, makes an appearance here, as well as the different house ghosts. Since you can go to any House, they all get a very detailed common room, and a positive I have to note about the game is how they made Slytherins not be complete jerks. Sure, it's always seen as the "evil house", but over here, while they're still very ambitious folk, most of them aren't hateful people, just a bit of overachievers. The professors you meet are also great characters, and while there may not be as many lessons as one would expect in a game that's all about being a Hogwarts student, you still get a nice taste of student life.All things considered, I must say I definitely recommend this game, and it's certainly a contender for my personal GOTY, though we'll have to see what else comes out this year.

author: Aletta
review: Fantastic game so far in the little time i've actually been able to play it since i've spent most of it TRYING TO FIX THE TERRIBLE STUTTERS. How are we at this point with PC builds of AAA games where they're actually unplayable because of stutters and fps dips. Regardless if I have everything on low or ultra, it doesnt matter.

author: Jedo
review: Hogwarts Legacy has been a wildly entertaining experience so far. I haven't touched anything related to the game since I finished all the OG books, but diving into this game brought back some fond memories from my childhood.I think the biggest part of this game that I loved is how it captured the vivid scenery of Hogsmeade as described in the books. The game also managed to deliver that first day of classes type excitement from year-to-year—albeit in a condensed late-bloomer 5th year package. So far, this game has been the best depiction of the wizarding world in game format. You honestly feel it the moment you get sorted and even more so when you first exit the school to travel to Hogsmeade! This game's open world is vast and beautiful, and I haven't been so happy to fully explore a game like this since Skyrim. In the blink of an eye, I noticed that 70h had gone by without me even thinking about it. If it wasn't obvious enough, I really enjoyed my time at Hogwarts.As far as performance goes, I recognize others with stronger GPUs had issues. Personally, I did not experience any major issues on my end with my RTX 2080. I maybe experienced stuttering for about 1-2 minutes total out of 70h of play, but relative to my peers I basically had a stress-free experience.The combat is beautiful and definitely has flashy moves, but I do think some of the cooler spells come a little bit too late into the story to fully enjoy. In that same breath, the ability to fly with your broom also feels like it comes quite late as well (or maybe it just felt that way because I was taking in the beautiful sights).When it comes to exploration, the huge amount of collectibles may be intimidating but they don't feel like a chore because majority of the collectibles serve a greater purpose than just non-essential pick-ups. Most of the collectible categories come with a good bit of lore to really enhance your understanding of that world, and the rest are polished cosmetics for either your character or base-building. It was actually fun collecting them all!My only gripe about this game which I'm sure will be fixed soon is that I am currently locked out of 100% because the Biscuit side quest's lock is bugged (I opened it prematurely) and won't spawn. I'm not too bothered about it though as every other element in the game was fun to play out through and through!! I know this game is very controversial, but even a bad parent (author) can raise an excellent child (story) that can outgrow them if given the right environment and attention. This game has grown bigger than its creator, and the developers+designers that worked on Hogwarts Legacy really put their love into it. It's really hard to create anything this beautiful if you come at it with a hateful heart. Give the game a fair look if you can be a partial person. Screw the author, but seriously the rest of the team did a great job.

review: /* /* /* /* /* Raising our wands in the honor of everyone who didn't make it to see their favorite franchise finally getting a huge & awesome game , RIP Robbie Coltrane (Hagrid) , Alan Rickman (Snape) and all the other amazing talents who are now in a better place /* /* /* /* /*

author: MrBrickfreak
review: It has come, after so many years and controversies the Avalanche studio finally released the one of the most anticipated games, the Hogwarts Legacy. As a youngster who grew up with Harry Potter books, I finally had the opportunity to visit the famous school of witchcraft and magic, and I am generally pleased. Almost every corner of the castle is actually full with nostalgia and magical charm that all truth fans might desire. The world is filled with details and exploring them is a lot of pleasure.But you can not get around and fly in the ointment: The Deluxe version was a horrible idea since allowing people to play the raw game for extra money is strange, especially because the game will recieve a first-day patch that will fix the difficulties the game had during first 72 hours, such as loading times and kind of bad-ish optimistation/performance even with 30 rtx series.It is truly wonderful to see such work being done by a company that previously only had expertise with Disney Infinity as a title of this size. I personally wish Avalnche the best of luck and hope to see more intriguing ventures in the future!

author: Lahang
review: A game that at a first glance feels amazing, both the art aspects of the game and the combat animations felt nice but... That's it, you are actually playing another "RPG" with the same formula commonly implemented by companies like Ubisoft, the typical generic structure that works as a basic rpg and that's it, don't expect wondrous features, special gameplay, none of what you are thinking will find it in here (the same generic structure that you could find not only at most recent Ubisoft rpgs -ACs-, but also from some games by WB Games as well, like Middleearth: Shadow of War).This game, that qualifies as a rpg because of this generic implemented formula, is a letdown, specially coming from someone who grew up with the HP saga (read the books and everything).Yea, you got Hogwarts to explore and everything, but you don't have the feeling of being a proper student at it, there's no class framework, you just attend one class for 1 or 2 times, then you are free forever to bs around the castle (expected something like famous Bully, from Rockstar, a system that makes you feel you are a student).Teachers that teach you spells that don't even belong to the classes they are teaching (Wingardium Leviosa, for example, a charm spell being teached by the professor in charge of Herbology, what?).Game lacks of spells tbh, and if you thought you could be a dark wizard (one of the main points some people bought the game, including me), it's all a LIE, yea, you get the three unforgivables, but the whole world doesn't react into you using them, you can't openly kill people, only designated enemies (other dark wizards and dirty goblins). No morality system what so ever.Even the main storyline, tricks you into choosing an outcome, but in reality, there's no evil ending, you can't be the Dark Lord Voldemort would be proud.Filling the whole game with collectibles in order to hide the fact that the side quests are kinda poorly written and boring, the whole "mini game" (let's call it that way) around taking "care" of beasts (felt like a cheap Tamagotchi attempt), how other students or even professors don't react if you start to cast around them in an unresponsible way, there's no crime/punishment system so to speak (like what Bully had for example).I could go on but that's basically it, a somewhat decent game by looks only, but with somewhat mediocre gameplay, an "rpg" game clearly designed to people who are not gamers, casuals and for potterheads who belong in the two previous categories mentioned. Expected much, much more from Hogwarts Legacy, just a *big* letdown. 6/10.Bonus Track: the whole thing about not including Quidditch was retarded as best, it's one of the main features any follower or HP fan will ask, and you don't need to read any book, just watch one of the frigging movies to realize that!

author: The Dogfather
review: WOW! Avalanche Games (not to be confused with the more famous Avalanche Studios) really came through. As a huge Harry Potter and Wizarding World fan, I honestly could not have imagined a more wonderful game based on this beloved property. Those initial trailers for the game got me really excited but if  taught me anything it was that a heavy dose of scepticism is often required when it comes to these AAA games but gee golly did Avalanche deliver. You can see that  was made by a team who really love and appreciate the property as much as any other fan.Hogwarts castle is massive (and when I mean massive it's huge) to explore. The open world is also really gorgeous and captures the look and feel of the movies perfectly.  Set at Hogwarts in the 1800's, your character is a student who holds the key to an ancient secret that threatens to tear the wizarding world apart and for the most part the main plot is downright exciting to experience as a long time fan (that end boss fight was one of the most intense fights I have ever had the pleasure of playing), the games magical combat turns out to be deep and rewarding and the side quests are really quite brilliant (most of them revolve around class mates that you befriend at the Academy) and some are really sweet while others are really bitter-sweet depending on the decisions you make. Some are downright sad. Other side quests revolve around the classes you will attend where you will usually learn a valuable spell or two to add to your repertoire.Sebastian Sallow's is particularly good. I highly encourage any player to complete it as it really tells an emotionally engaging story. I even loved Poppy Sweeting's story arc (what a little sweet heart on her crusade to save all creatures from poachers) and Natsai “Natty” Onai, who comes from Zimbabwe, South Africa's neighbour, and being African myself I could really identify with her) proved to be a true friend in the end.I was in Gryffindor so I never got to see the other character side quests as each house has its own. This was honestly one of the most enjoyable games I have ever played and that $150 million Warner Bros. spent on the making of this game was really put to good use. I mean hello, it made over $850 million in its launch week. The only issue is performance is a bit spotty, especially in the castle, but I got 95% of my field guide complete with lots of exploring of the open world map hence the 121 hours, your playtime may vary so please don't let my duration put you off. Otherwise, as a fan,  was an absolute pleasure to play and I highly recommend it.

Choices dont matter.Interacting with the world is very littleCombatbase is great but it gets boring fast because it stays the same level no matter your levelGet the game in sale if you want.

author: Titan Uranus
review: Stop giving exclusives to consoles. Playstation owners get access to the Haunted Hogsmeade quest, which includes access to an extra dungeon, the Shopkeeper's cosmetic set, and access to a special Hogsmeade shop in which you own. The Haunted Hogsmeade quest should've been a DLC. This is a big failure on Avalanche and Portkey. Because of this, I'm leaving a negative review. With this many players, they would've made way more money off of it as a DLC than with any contract as an exclusive - Especially since the Dark arts pack is listed at $20 USD. Imagine what they would've been able to charge for Haunted Hogsmeade with a questline, a shop, and cosmetics - $50 USD? Stop giving exclusives to consoles.

author: manollette
review: This is less of an "I don't recommend this game" and more of an "I'd hold off on a good sale for this game". Hogwarts Legacy does a lot of things right. It really captures the "feel" of the HP universe, and the story, setting, and world are everything I hoped they'd be for a game like this set in a universe I grew up reading about. It really feels like you're a student at Hogwarts.The wand combat is a little easy - which is not helped by how dumb the AI is in a fight - but it flows incredibly well. Switching between spell sets is intuitive & fast, and it's very fun to watch. Most enemies in the game have mechanics that allow you to kill them with incredible ease, if you use the right spell/combo at the right time. Flight controls are pretty clunky and awkward to get down. The facial expressions are pretty 'uncanny valley' creepy at times, and the voice acting can be quite bad (and quite good) in places. My character sounds incredibly spiteful spitting out the incantation for 'Crucio', but when I get it cast on me in a cinematic, my guy sounds like the pain he's experiencing is on par with banging your shin on a piece of furniture. The main story is also nothing special; very generic bad guy stuff. The side stories are far more interesting. The first bad note for me is that replayability is nonexistent and your choices don't matter. "Be the wizard you want to be" for WB apparently equates to "Be the cookie cutter good guy we've shoehorned you into being, but you can make a small selection of decisions, kind of, at the end of the game right before it ends and nothing else happens". Decisions that should be impactful barely get a little end-of-story "and then this happened" blurb. Following that, HOLY HELL did they try to shove every time-waster they could fit into this game. HL is the epitome of collector games. "Collect your magic sources, collect the balloons, collect the landing pads, collect the trials, collect the animals, collect the plants". As a completionist, I haven't been this bored out of my mind since playing the first Assassin't Creed games collecting the 100 little flags or whatever. The amount of inane, pointless collection in this game is absolutely obscene to me, and easily 3/4 of my 60-hour playthrough was just going around collecting garbage. If I had just focused on the quests, this would've been a 15-hour game. If I just did the main quest, it'd probably clock in at a bit under 10. And that's the main reason for the negative review: even though the core of the game is good, there's way too much filler, and no game that is only good for one playthrough, that would take a reasonable person under 10 hours to finish, is worth $60. If this ever goes for half off, absolutely buy it - it was certainly a fun ~15 hours.

author: Rain
review: Words can't describe how disappointed I am in this game. This was advertised as "make your own path" kind of game, yet it can't be further away from the truth. There is one path, and it's the one the game gives you. There is no becoming a dark wizard, or a good one... you're just the character the game tells you to be.The whole game is lifeless, NPCs don't react to anything you do, you can talk to some of them but that's it. You can go around casting spells, no one will even look at you or react the slightest. You can go and enter people's house after forcing their locks, go through their chests, they won't say or do a thing, they just act like you're not even there. Most of the time you can't jump to places, invisible walls everywhere, making exploration very linear and flavorless. Combat is fun, but I'm still looking for difficulty. Basically entered one of the most dangerous places, the Forbidden Forest, after 2 hours playing and defeated everything that came my way without breaking a sweat, there is no real danger or even sense of danger, and of course you can't attack centors, because yeah... you're not a bad person, so the game won't let you do bad things. You can fly on a broom, and again, it's slow, no sensation or feeling of speed, you can go into an obstacle at full speed and you will just stop, no impact, no animation, nothing. You just stop like it's okay to ram into a wall. The only decent thing about the game so far is the story. It's well designed, for now, but there is not much choices or decisions to take, and the only few really don't change anything to the story... you just go with it and follow the game's lead. It's basically a playable cinematic.So to sum it up, it is yet again a very expensive game that brings nothing new to the table, with empty promises and seemingly half finished features. Was expecting this to be a Skyrim with HP world, turned out to be a plain adventure game you can't even play with your friends.4/10EDIT: So... difficulty got better, after turning it to difficult, it gets interesting if you face multiple enemies at once. That being said, I still think it's a bit weird that our character, a 15 years old student, can take on dark mages and other such threats so easily, but that's just how the game was made I guess.I've just finished the story, it was okay, nothing incredible, not bad either...  Some of you have mentionned NPCs reacting to certain things.. so I went ahead and tried all that. So yes, you get a line of reaction here and there when you cast a forbidden spell, but that's honestly just not enough. Lines are always the same, and that leads to pretty much nothing. What I was trying to mention is more like RDR2 type of reaction. Stand too close to someone, they'll ask you to move, make a mess, pay the consequences, etc.Of course i'm aware this was not exactly advised, BUT. The description clearly says "Be the wizard you want to be" among other things, and the rest probably was just my expectations, yes. We're in 2023, this is an AAA game, it's advised as open world, RPG. I REALLY thought they would at least add some RPG element, and somewhat lively NPCs.I have read some people saying I was picky, talking about the broom, but in my opinion, such details are what make a game great. I remember people complaining that you could just get out of a full speed moving car in Cyberpunk, and your char would be standing on the road as if nothing happened. This is the same level of details. You can fly full speed on your broom and hit everything on your way, you won't be falling, ever.I also read from the comment that, at some point, you can make choices, etc... I've currently finished the main story, and yes, I did have some choices to make. But what good are they if they don't mean nothing to your game experience? Like... just go throwing forbidden curses everywhere, people will still greet you the same, everywhere. You don't exist to their eyes, and they don't give a damn wwhat you do, which is also exactly why you can spend the night roaming the forbidden forest instead of being in your bed at school and no one will ever wonder what you're doing and where you've been. You've got an ultimate choice to make at the end of the story, literally a "Are you good or evil?" kind of choice, and whatever your answer is makes absolutely no difference... that's just empty choices.I'm currently trying out mods, and some of them might just make the game a bit better.And lastly, it seems some of you got triggered because I kept playing the game despite my review. As it clearly says, I find the story decent, and I still wish to finish it. Also at no point I said the game was bad. I think, and again, this is my opinion, that it's too expensive for what it currently is, and that it could have been a complete banger if only they would have worked on it some more to add modern RPG features before releasing it. But it does have some good points, as mentionned, combat is fun, at least for now, and the world is well detailed, which makes it even more of a pity that there isn't much to do in it aside from the same old puzzles we've known for years.If you like the game, it's cool for you, honestly. This is just some point that made me disappointed in the game, expectations or not. Go ahead and tell me why you like it, instead of acting like I've just insulted your family.Good gaming people.

author: DRACER
review: Harry Potter: Hogwarts Legacy is a magical adventure that will transport you to the wizarding world like never before. The game immerses you in the world of Hogwarts and offers a unique experience unlike any other Harry Potter game or movie.The graphics are stunning and bring the iconic Hogwarts Castle, the Forbidden Forest, and Hogsmeade Village to life. The attention to detail is impressive, from the spells you cast to the creatures you encounter. The game's soundtrack is also enchanting, setting the perfect mood for your journey through the wizarding world.One of the highlights of the game is the character customization feature, which allows you to create your own wizard or witch and personalize their appearance, abilities, and spells. The game's story is well written, and it offers a captivating adventure that will keep you engaged for hours. You will be able to explore the castle and interact with familiar characters from the Harry Potter universe, such as Professor Snape and Albus Dumbledore.The game's spellcasting system is intuitive and satisfying, and it offers a sense of power and control that is unmatched by other games in the genre. The combat system is also well executed, and it provides a challenge without being overly difficult.If I had any complaint, your character feels too "solo" at times, I didn't feel like I made many meaningful connections.In conclusion, Harry Potter: Hogwarts Legacy is an exceptional game that will captivate both fans of the Harry Potter franchise and gamers who love action-packed adventures. It offers an immersive experience that will transport you to the wizarding world and leave you spellbound.

author: Amjara
review: I will keep it brief as many have already stated in their review, this game is simply magical. They fleshed out the books and the movies of Harry Potter and made every aspect of the world come alive.  spent the first 8 hours of my time in just Hogwarts marvelling and getting lost while looking for collectables and lore. A huge thank you to Avalanche for making the game we all wanted. It was crafted with love by people who love the wizardling world. And it shows. This game is in my top 5 of all time, and worth your time and money. I am 30 hours in and have so much more to experience. Keep the hate and the politics out of your games, your life will be better if you just play games to have fun. That is what they are meant for. It might have taken over 20 years to get here but finally your invitation to Hogwarts has arrived!  💌

author: sul
review: Enchanting, mesmerizing, captivating, bewitching, whimsical, fantastic. These are all magical words, and they’re some of the few words I’d use to describe Hogwarts Legacy, so make of that what you will, or read the rest of my thoughts on this incredible game.Hogwarts Legacy has been, to me at least, a magical journey in the full meaning of the word. It has taken me back to my childhood, where my obsession with Harry Potter was a bittersweet escape from reality. It is a hard thing to pull off to centralize this kind of fantasy, and it has been a thing millions of people always dreamed of for decades, it’s understandably hard for any game developer to satisfy the immense scope of the expectations for a game that promises more or less an adventure as a student in Hogwarts, I had always been highly skeptical of this game as a result, point of fact, when I saw the first gameplay showcases late last year, I wrote this game off. I was like “yep, this is trash”. Suffice to say that I have swallowed my words since then, and I have been proven thoroughly wrong, and now count the game as one of my most treasured experiences in video games.One word; Huge. 120+ hours later I still don’t have its layout mapped in my head, and I’m still now discovering new secret locations even after combing so many parts of the castle many times. It has so much of the iconic locations from the films and books. The great hall, the iconic courtyard in front of it, the creaky wooden bridge, the grand staircase, and much more.Throughout my engaging playthrough of the game, the school itself was, for the most part, consigned to the background, while the story of the game unfolded, or while I explored the beautiful world. At the end, Hogwarts felt exactly just that; a backdrop. Most classes, what few there are, are just a cool introductory cutscene, from then on, the teachers will give you ‘assignments’ to learn more spells. The classes are more or less presented as missions rather than a routine activity or part of the school, and as I went more and more through the game and performed some cursory retrospect of my playthrough, I quickly realized that the time I spent in the school itself was but a minority of my entire playthrough.My experience with Hogwarts Legacy’s massive open world is hard to sum up it. Every time I thought I discovered most of the map, I’m immediately surprised to know that there’s a whole new uncharted realm that I haven’t been to. Idyllic glades and creeks giving way to the most charming of villages, mountains and ridges crowned with the ruins of long-lost castles, cliffsides pockmarked by mines, tunnels and caverns astride them, dense forests concealing ancient barrows, all consecrated in a whimsical atmosphere meant that I lost track of time when I was going through this beautiful world. It’s so full of amazing things to do or discover that I never felt a moment of tedium even after spending 110 hours into the game, most of which were spent combing this huge world. There are also 3 seasons, each isn't just a dressing, it adds some cool interaction to the world, like snowmen who fight you in winter. The open world features many of the famous locations from the books & films, the Hogwarts Express, Hogsmeade, The Forbidden Forest, etc. And it’s mindboggling how much detail and care was put into presenting all of these. Every iconic location is in of itself a world. There are 27 spells in the game, including the famous unforgiveable curses, and some consumable items like mandrakes (AOE stun) or Chinese chomping cabbages (ferocious critters that attack enemies) and the Thunderbrew potion which calls a miniature thunderstorm over enemies. The spells offer a pretty wide variety of combo possibilities, you can juggle small enemies in the air, tossing them back and forth, up and down, freezing them, transforming them into crates or even explosive barrels (which you can then toss at other enemies), and outside of the spells your character also possesses a special affinity towards “ancient magic” that allows them to just OHKO enemies either by calling thunder on them, blowing them up into smithereens, transforming them into chickens, pick up objects around the world & toss them at enemies, etc.The game pushes you into its story brusquely in the first cutscene, framing the background of your character who is capable of seeing and crudely manipulating the “Ancient Magic”, so off the start, your PC already has the “I’m the chosen one” badge. This might sound unappealing, but fortunately the game doesn’t go ham with this theme and handles it really well. Beyond core narrative, there is an adventure that awaits in Hogwarts. The PC will meet many students, form close bonds with them, and some of them are really, really well written and compelling characters (especially Sebastian Sallow). These characters will oscillate between being parts of main story questlines and being secondary/side characters, if you will get this game make absolutely certain to play their questlines because the writing is really *chef’s kiss* so good and I enjoyed their quests very much.The 3 main student friends you will meet in Hogwarts are Natsai Onai (Gryffindor), Sebastian Sallow (Slytherin) and Poppy Sweeting (Hufflepuff). Unfortunately for some reason Ravenclaw doesn’t have a major story character (though I enjoyed Samantha Dale’s quest very much). Outside of major house reps, there is a lot of other students you’ll meet and do errands for throughout the school. There are several compelling villains, some the player will bring the fight to, some will bring the fight to the player, some can only be fought in side quests. You will slowly discover more and more about them, and some aspects of them seemed to have been red herrings (which the narrative has a healthy amount).The soundtrack is  and is mostly inspired by the music score from the first two HP Movies composed by John Williams, but there are some tracks that feel more reminiscent of the 5th and 6th movies. Some tracks like "Soaring Above Hogwarts" give me goosebumps 90% of the time I hear them. There is unfortunately a dearth of player agency, though the game presents a long list of dialogue choices, most of them are for flavor, but some will have story consequences (such as deciding a character’s fate). There are 3 different endings (but they don’t have any requirements, it’s more like you decide what your witch or wizard will do with something they find at the end). Most side quests will have multiple options at the end. One of the byproducts of the huge scope of this game is that they added a lot of sandbox stuff to the side, mainly condensed in the Room of Requirement (RoR). It’s something you’ll unlock about 1/4th into the game, the game gives you a room and free reign to customize it however you please. You can collect or purchase hundreds of items, furniture, décor to put into this room. And the amazing thing is that it also iteratively grows throughout the game, adding several Vivariums where you can keep magical beasts you collect across the world, these Vivariumae, each unique and different, are in turn customizable with a different pool of stuff.It was hard to write this. When I finished writing my first draft of this, it was really huge. I'd write way more if I could but review char limit. Yes, you should get this wonderful game.

author: Reisender
review: Meh. Stylistically the game is great. The castle feels pretty alive and and it has many of the environmental elements I would expect from Hogwarts. The environments/areas outside the castle are similarly polished.Unfortunately, such appearances only go skin deep. There is very limited interactivity with your environment outside of the scripted quests or the various treasure hunt type items. You can't interact with any of the people that aren't vendors or active in a given quest, can't sit down in a chair or on a bench, no real commentary on player actions whatsoever. I have yet to feel drawn into the world as none of the characters are ever really present to engage with. I have no companions unless they are needed for a quest, there are no rivalries to be had (which is rather more noticeable as I went Slytherin) and that's well before any of the immersion breaking progressive nonsense is added in. Short of it is, I don't ever feel like a student at Hogwarts, I feel like a "Mary Sue'd" outsider partaking in a magical murder mystery theater.Speaking of quests, they are also "meh" for the most part. The main quest line is rather engaging and keeps you moving forward to find out what happens next, but the side quests are quite boring and often just boil down to your standard "go fetch" type quests. I have not found any side quest of substance as of yet.Combat is one of the saving graces so far. Generally quite intuitive and enjoyable. Presents a decent challenge while also making you feel like a spell slinging bad-ass on occasion.Oh, and the loot.  Seriously the loot system and types of loot is ridiculous.  The mechanics aren't horrible, but the immersion break is.  My eyes ache from the rolling whenever, after traversing an "ancient" dungeon/crypt/cave, bypassing puzzles, slaying enemies, etc. I then spy an impressive looking chest, only to open said chest and be awarded with... a new scarf/house robe/glasses. -.-  Still have a ways to go in the game, so I'm gonna keep an open mind till I complete the game, but so far... Meh.

author: Pitvypyr
review: I half expected Hagrid to show up and say "You're a wizard, Pitvypyr!", but alas, he was a no-show. After almost 80 hours into the game, I've had a generally good experience. It's been fun so far, however, there are a few things that have left me disappointed. I was seriously upset over the broom system. I mean, all the brooms are the same, except for upgrades. You should have gotten a Nimbus 2000 and flown out of the Hogwarts courtyard, and THEN when you got the Firebolt, you should have been able to hit the afterburner and gone from map edge to map edge within a few seconds. But nope, that fell flat. And another gripe is the Merlin tests. After you solve each test, couldn't they have made a way to disable the Merlin animation?? I'm getting flashbacks of skinning animals from my Red Dead Redemption 2 days. That seriously gets old. And the cave layouts could have been better designed. Instead...you run a few feet, turn left (or right) then another turn and you're at a chest. Open said chest and back outside, then it's over. Yeah, some have a few puzzles, but the majority are the same ol' same. Also, where is the spell upgrade for Revelio? I wanted an option to have this spell be extended for at least a min. Instead, you're spamming that spell like there is no tomorrow. And I don't think I've used any of the potions (except Thunderbrew) since I had to brew a Focus potion and drink it for one of the class requirements. It would have been nice to have these extended too. Maybe doing more potion classes and learning to squeeze a bezoar with a side of a knife instead of slicing it...and then learning to extend the potion's effects for longer than 15 seconds?? Seems like you'd be spamming those things too in the middle of a long fight. That's one of the reasons I don't use them. After you get out into the big wide world, the grind becomes real, it seems. And another gripe...why didn't they have a 5th spell set for using it in the Vivarium as well. I mean, putting the bag, the feed, the brush, etc...on the vivarium spell set would have been nice. instead, you're having to move everything around to brush your beasts for that all-important hair/feather. I feel they could have tweaked the game more. And another thing, I just don't see the draw for skins/outfits unless they actually served a purpose. I played a sniping game where I got a ghillie suit. I thought to myself, "Nice, I can be more invisible." But it didn't do anything to help you in the game at all. The enemy could see you just as well with it on, as off. So with all the different hats/glasses/gloves in this game, I usually change the appearance back to a generic hat and don't use any of the different styles in the game. Skins just don't appeal to me. But after all this griping, don't get me wrong, I really enjoy the game, but the latter half is just monotonous.

author: Pride
review: If you're a HP fan, it's a must.If you don't care about HP and have something else to play, probably wait for performance fixes & sale.If you don't care about HP and don't have anything else to play, go for it. Game has massive fps drops, memory leaks and occasional crashes on a more than decent rig, even after day 1 'performance' hotfix. Things that helped me greatly:1. Installing Ascendio mod from Nexusmods.2. Swapping DLSS version to latest with DLSS Swapper (free app btw).3. Turning off ray tracing and VSync in game settings.The story and puzzles are mediocre. Game is rather linear. Where it thrives for me personally is combat, it features some souls-like elements, spell combos, potion and plant usage. But I barely died in fights even on hard difficulty. Don't go for anything lower than hard unless you're a casual.Overall, for me as a HP fan, it's 10/10. You can traverse Hogwarts, discover secret rooms, talk to ghosts, use a variety of spells, learn unforgivable curses, get some relics, visit legendary Ollivander shop and much, MUCH more. All the things I dreamed of since I read my first HP book. For me as a gamer, disregarding my HP affection, the game is 6.5/10.I did greatly enjoy the game but do not wish to support devs releasing AAA games in the current state as well as releasing console exclusive content (you can open your own shop in Hogsmeade is you're a lucky owner of PS5, but for us poor PC plebs performance issues is the only exclusive for now), hereby leaving a negative review.
