author: buura
review: Hello to all game enthusiasts..I've never written a review for a game, but I couldn't resist this one..Yes, I love the Harry Potter universe. Let's start with that:Every scene and every landscape in the game is a masterpiece. Each element has been carefully crafted, and it's clear that a lot of effort has been put into it.The game truly reflects the world we imagined from the books. The visuals from the movies and books have been brilliantly synthesized. Instead of using the names from the original story to sell the game, they've been carefully avoided. The references are just right. The game takes place in the 1800s, so there's a different teaching staff, different enemies, and different problems. The variety of enemies and the way the story progresses gave me the feeling of detective work that I had in the books, and like in the books, you find yourself in the middle of a big problem, and you collect bits of information from the many events around you. The story telling in the game, and the progression of information and mystery, made me very happy.The game, like classic Harry Potter games, is full of puzzles that you have to solve and hidden secrets that you have to uncover all around the castle, and solving these and working for them is really fun.The graphics are beyond great. I didn't encounter any bugs or optimization problems. The spell effects, inspired by the movie, are fantastic and look great. I can't find anything to say about the design of the school, it's perfect. Even after spending a long time, it still continues to enchant.Regarding the music, the original music from the movie was not abandoned, and generally new fantastic music has been created based on that theme.The story has a completely new Hogwarts and teaching staff. The characteristics of the teaching staff are completely different from the original story. For example, you may not see the professor of dark arts as a bad character. They have characters that are quite intriguing. In terms of voice acting, they've found a voice that's very similar to Daniel Radcliffe's, and generally his reactions are compatible with Harry Potter. This didn't bother me.The only thing I think the game is missing is that the chosen school sections could be a bit more effective. I would have liked more specific tasks for the chosen section after selection, and more tasks for your section...In conclusion, the game is amazing. It is not unrealistic to think that the producer will make us happy with new tasks and expansions in the future.I wish everyone good games and I definitely recommend playing this game.

author: Jono
review: I'd just like to say that I don't really write many reviews for games all that much, however there's a specific exception for Hogwarts Legacy. I'm a huge fan of the Harry Potter series and having read the books and watched the movies, this was something that had caught my eye for many years!As many others have already mentioned, this game feels like such a well worked piece of art, in which the devs have really taken their time with constructing the most true to life game possible, whilst staying true to the nature of Hogwarts. I have no doubt that future optimization patches further down the line will help smoothen out some FPS drops that many seem to be reporting, including myself. The soundtrack is beautiful and the audio in this game really needs to be experienced with headphones on for the full immersion experience. If you're a fan of Harry Potter in general, I would highly recommend this game. Even if you're not and would like to experience a beautiful open world RPG with the ability to learn many spells, meet fun and new characters, and enjoy collecting and exploring a great world, then I'd recommend this game too at full price.Take care and happy gaming team :)

author: Azael
review: Hollow game that's only impressive on a shallow surface level. Gameplay quickly becomes tedious and uninspired. The entire world feels like a bland Assassins Creed game with a million pointless completionist tasks that bare no significance to anything or anyone. Ironically, there's no sense of magic in this game at all. Attend Hogwarts for a whopping 8 hours of school-time and watch cutscenes so you don't have to experience the tedium of class life, fly slowly and with great limitation to exotic locations such as Hill and Rocks, or Paddock, perhaps the illustrious NPC Village of static dialogue. Visit and explore Hogsmeade; In under 10 minutes because there's literally nothing to do there except buy a few things. Murder hundreds of humans and goblins along the way, whilst bitterly murmuring about the diabolical things these witches and wizards are planning. Evil deeds that can only be halted and disrupted by the angelic magic prodigy that is the stout and dependable "Shlemhrimhrer," named aptly because companies don't know how to be PC without being absurd. I don't think the people who raved on about and rated this game so highly have ever played an actual decent open world game. Or any RPG.

author: Halo
review: After nearly 30 hours of playing, I just wanna say that my time with the game has been brilliant, and I highly recommend it as a fun open world game. Combat is pretty fun and can be challenging, even on the normal difficulty; and the story is not that bad, either. PC version has some technical issues, you might have to force yourself to play on Low settings until the devs patch the game. Nonetheless, if you have the money, go for it 👍However, I know there are MANY people unsure out of fear of backlash from friends or rando's on the internet due to the IP being owned by J. K. Rowling. Trust me, I hate her too and am annoyed with the nonsense she spouts from her bigoted brain of hers, I DO NOT support her views or values whatsoever. That doesn't mean I can't enjoy anything that came from what OTHERS have made based from her world; I still enjoy the movies, and I most certainly am enjoying Hogwarts Legacy.You are not a terrible person for getting this game, you are not a transphobe, you are not aiding in her already deep pockets. You are valid, you should do what you want. Boycott if you want to boycott, but DO NOT bully or harass others for buying/playing this game. If you REALLY care that much, use the $60 to donate towards a charity that benefits those that J.K. hates so much. Remove the art from the artist; if the very same actors who have played their role in the Harry Potter movies DISOWN and REMOVE THEMSELVES from J.K. and her ideals, then you can too.

author: Arkimedes
review: Performance/bugs:My config: Ryzen 5 3600 (X570 chipset), 32GB DDR4 3600Mhz, RTX 3060 OC (12gb), Gen3 SSDI played in 1080p with 60 fps limit and it was running at constant 60fps (no raytracing, DLSS set to quality, all settings on ultra).I finished the game in about 75 hours (I did all sidequests and most challenges) and I didn't encounter any crashes, performance issues or game breaking bugs.Bethesda should really pay attention!Gameplay:It's not a perfect game but I really enjoyed it and it has great potential with future MODs and hopefully DLC.I love the movies and this game looks incredible. Architecture, textures, sounds, atmosphere,... everything feels like straight out of the movies.And most importantly there are NO MICROTRANSACTIONS ! (those would be a deal breaker for me)Combat is enjoyable and can be great fun when trying new spell combinations or making use of the environment.Definitely better than Witcher 3.The biggest downside are the challenges.I mean they are pretty good and there is great variety, however you have to do them too many times.Merlin trials were very anoying and too repetitive for me because I wanted maximum inventory size.Despite that I really enjoyed just run or fly around and explore without knowing where I'm going or what to expect ahead.I also spent lot of time decorating my room of requirement and magical worlds for my creatures.But I was expecting more assets so there it definitely room for improvement either by patches,DLC or probably most likely MODs.Increasing creature limit would be nice as 12 is way too small.Definitely looking forward playing this one again in a year or so with some cool MODs or DLCs.

author: Arek
review: I'm not a Harry Potter fan and even so the game has been amazing, so I imagine a fan will tear up with the attention to detail and overall quality.The game allows you to focus on the main story and completionists will find a ton of all type of collectibles and puzzles spread all over the open world, specially in the Hogwarts Castle and Hogsmeade. I thought they would be a chore, but the game has several ways to point out what you're missing and where, although you may need help with a guide in a few occasions.It doesn't really have any innovation in its mechanics, but it uses good known formulas for open-world RPGs (level, spells and item progression, character and item customization, a small player hub that will expand throughout the adventure and allows you to customize all sort of cosmetics/decoration, and lots of lore, secrets and references to be found.

author: Serene
review: Hogwarts Legacy lets you roleplay as a Costco version of Newt Scamander , raise questionable plants and run around the castle  putting your grubby little mitts on everything.  If that isn't the definitive Hogwarts Experience I don't know what is.         Jokes aside Hogwarts legacy does a great job in effortlessly letting you into the world. The castle is exceptionally well made and running around exploring it a joy.  The combat is a blast as you have a veritable arsenal of familiar spells to play around with.                                                                                                                            I do have minor gripes about not having mandatory classes everyday but that's just me.  The game feels like it's optimised really well as aside from a few minor drops in fps whilst outside , it runs well.Overall if you loved The Wizarding World as a kid, you'll have an absolute blast playing it and if not ,the games is still fun enough to keep you engaged

author: mojo priest
review: One of the game's positive aspects is the feeling that the developers have managed to create. As a player, it really does feel like you're at Hogwarts, with all of the familiar settings, characters, and spells.However, the game's biggest problem is the extremely boring gameplay. All of the puzzles are too easy, and if you do happen to struggle, your character will start thinking out loud and reveal the solution within five seconds. A good chunk of the quests revolve around farming items rather than engaging in immersive story quests, making the gameplay tedious and repetitive.Another issue with the game is that it feels lifeless, lacking any random events or anything to make the world feel alive. This makes exploring the world feel like a chore, rather than an adventure.Some other problems:* You can stand right next to your teachers and cast forbidden spells like Crucio without them even reacting. * You don't have the ability to make choices that significantly impact the game's outcome* Finally, the game's quest system is outdated, with the game constantly reminding you to return to your quest, making it feel more like a game from the year 2000 than a modern RPGOverall, while the feeling of being at Hogwarts is well-executed, the game's boring gameplay, lifeless world, lack of consequences, and outdated quest system make it a disappointment for those expecting an immersive and engaging experience.

author: Toothcake
review: I was 10 when the first Harry Potter book came out. I couldn't get into it. My fandom was established with the movies, and even though I enjoy them, I'm not what I would consider a huge Harry Potter fan. But my wife is, and because of her, I've gotten to see the full breadth of what this game is. At several points in the game, she started crying despite herself. She'd get mad about it, chuckle, and then carry on only to be gobsmacked by some other tiny detail that only she could appreciate as a fan of the books. In her words, the devs understood and captured the appeal of why everyone wanted to live in the Wizarding World. Say what you will about the controversy surrounding the HP universe, but I think it's clear that the devs put a lot of love into making a Hogwarts that is for everyone. Mechanics-wise, it's similar to other WB games but the Rock-Paper-Scissors-Confringo combat is frantic enough to be consistently interesting. The side quests are actually interesting and fit within the overall narrative. The only downside is that quite a few of them are collect-a-thons of varying flavors. If you're a lore nerd, then you'll be pleased.Oh, and despite what's been reported prior to the official launch, your House choice DOES actually make a difference. My wife and I had two different approaches to a quest based on House choice, with both of us meeting characters and visiting locations that the other didn't. My gripes are minor and deal more with the immersive qualities in RPGs. You can't sit, the cats meow sounds weirdly demonic when you pet them, and there isn't much reason to spend time in any of the spaces when you're not questing or collecting. I kinda wanted a Bully-style immersive game, but I understand why they went with the approach that ultimately shipped. Haven't finished it yet, but I am happy with what I've played.
